title: What is wrong with you people?
body: Every single game now, someone is blaming, raging, trolling, or just leaving the game... and I've been playing nothing but urf. Seriously, just stop and take a breath.  Try to actually have *fun*.

replies.body: The game isn't designed to be fun, it's designed to be competitive.

>
> The game isn't designed to be fun, it's designed to be competitive.

URF was totes designed to be competitive yep.
Sadly I have to agree with you, it seams that casuals no longer matter to riot unless they pay money.
That doesn't even make sense. There's nothing in the store that divides a hardcore player from a casual one. Absolutely nada.

you misunderstand my meaning.. Weather your a casual or a hardcore trying to get into championships if you dont spend money on RP the ONLY skins you get are victorious, and the amount of time needed to make rune pages and get new champs is drastically extended. 

To put this in perspective, I can drop ten dollars and get a new champ and a skin, with alittle over for an icon or small IP boost, and only spend 20-40 hrs on runes for that champ, or, i can spend 40-80 hours to get the same thing without money, and still not have a skin.

Riot has NO rewards for casual players that dont do ranked, and dont spend money. If you want a skin, at minimum you have to get to gold, unless you want to drop money.

That's like one skin per season. If you want a skin, buy one of the many in the store. It's not really a reward for anything though... it just shows you were willing to spend $5 of your well-earned cash on a cosmetic item. For casual players, there are plenty of icons that are attainable by participating in events and such. 

This game will never really be about long term rewards, unless you decide to climb through the ranked ladder. I've never even touched ranked, and I've been playing since season two (okay, I did play one ranked game a while back.) I play because I feel rewarded by the small victories I achieve while in a match, winning a game, improving, or grinding IP for a champion/runes. 

If you find owning skins rewarding, just buy them... if you don't have money, then save some up, cut spending, sell something, wait tables once a week (seriously, just work for like 3 hours and earn $40-$200... plenty of skins to buy with that) If you have an internet connection and time to play a game, I don't really see why you can't get the skin you want. I'll never understand a person's "need" for skins though. I have quite a few myself, but I could take 'em or leave 'em.

And besides, if you're willing to pay actual money for virtual things, you may not be as casual as you think. Unless you're rich, that's dedication in itself.

I disagree with AFK. If you're referring to League of Legends in general, your statement might have some merit, but U.R.F. is definitely intended to be fun and not competitive. Anytime there is a game that has minimal consideration to balance(as is the case in U.R.F), it is by definition not designed to be competitive. Take a painstakingly balanced game and add a ridiculous buff to EVERYONE, even if it doesn't apply to everyone. .. that's not balanced.

Yeah for the first 2 days, it was the most amazing thing to hit League.  Now it's just another flavor of playing with unpunished trolls.
Idk, but something must have happen between season 3 to season 5.
League got popular so more people started playing. More people= chances running into these kind of people increases
I guess i meant, perhaps a new group joined league that made it less desirable to play. Like fotm people or kdr people. Or perhaps the balancing became unstable.

Not necessarily. If league is more popular, than the relative number of toxic players should stay the same; I would presume that the people who like to play league would be a relatively consistent audience. I mean, logically speaking, the fact that there are more people doesn't say anything about what percentage of them are toxic. Now if you said "League of Legends have become more popular with people that normally play Call of Duty," then I could see your point because this game can be quite frustrating for people used to team-deathmatch style battles of "I have more kills, so I win."

Also, because people always think that my examples come from hard fact for some reason, I personally don't know how many people who play call of duty also play league of legends... it was just an example of something that would make more sense, if it were true.

Maybe they're having fun playing the OP champs? I mean, kill potential is a huge draw to most people, so obviously they're going to pick something they like with high kill potential.

I was playing Sona because having a passive proc every two seconds is incredibly satisfying, not because 'omg she's op, that means I'll win'. She's been banned lately so I've been building Ahri with Banner and Zz'rot Portal and having a blast with that too.

Well, that's what happens when people stick with the previously mentioned mentality. I was just screwing around earlier tonight by building straight AP on Riven for the hell of it. I got my ass handed to me lol, but it was fun. I was actually happy that my teammates didn't get an attitude with me.

In regards to URF, its a game mode created to be fun, if a player takes URF games too seriously then they shouldn't be playing. That being said I mostly play normals and I try to have fun (I still play to win, but I don't take things too seriously to the point where I'm over competitive). League is a competitive game but I feel that the ranked games are where a majority of that should go to; League is a game, you should be enjoying the game.
